relationships.evidence: pharmacotherapy, especially selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors antidepressants, remains the most frequent option for treating depression during the acute phase.
electroconvulsive therapy is the most effective somatic therapy for depression in some specific situations.
depression-focused psychotherapy is the second most common option for helping patients overcome the acute phase, maintain remission, and prevent relapses.
combining medications, psychotherapy, and somatic therapies remains the most effective way to manage resistant forms of depression.
treatment during the acute phase of a major depressive episode aims to help the patient reach a remission state.
maois have demonstrated specific efficacy in treating depression with atypical features.
tcas are about as effective as other classes of antidepressants in treating major depression.
ssris have demonstrated comparable efficacy to tcas in treating major depression.
snris are generally considered effective as ssris in treating major depression.
ssris are recommended as the first-line treatment for patients with major depression.
in individual studies, venlafaxine and duloxetine are generally considered effective as ssris.
the hamilton depression is commonly used to measure remission in depression.
ketamine has very effects on resistant unipolar depression.
esketamine was approved by the united states food and drug administration in march 2019 for treatment-resistant depression.
the antidepressant effect of ketamine can persist for several days but eventually wanes.
esketamine use must be carefully monitored due to potential risks, but it is used for treatment-resistant depression.
the hamilton depression is commonly used to assess outcomes in depression treatment.
cbt is a well-known effective treatment method for mdd.
ipt is a first-line treatment for mild to moderate major depressive episodes in adults.
supportive therapy is commonly used to support depressed patients.
psychoeducational intervention has been recommended for patients with depression.
mindfulness-based cognitive therapy is proposed to maintain and prevent depression.
the european psychiatric association recommends using the cognitive behavioral analysis system of psychotherapy for treating chronic depression.
problem-solving therapy has been used in different clinical situations, like preventing depression among the elderly.
marital and family therapy is effective in treating some aspects of depression.
cbt is a well-known effective treatment method for mdd.
ipt is a first-line treatment for mild to moderate major depressive episodes in adults.
supportive therapy is commonly used to support depressed patients.
psychodynamic therapy’s efficacy in the acute phase of mdd is well-established compared to other forms of psychotherapy.
supportive gt and group cbt reduce depressive symptoms.
studies have shown that eight weeks of mbct treatment during remission reduces relapse.
ect is the most well-known treatment for resistant depression, and solid evidence supports its effectiveness and safety.
recent literature shows a significant difference between rtms and fictitious stimulation regarding its improvements in depressive symptoms.
the tdcs technique significantly outperforms the simulator in terms of the rate of response and remission.
the antidepressant effects of tdcs may involve long-term neuroplastic changes that continue to occur even after the acute phase of treatment.
preliminary research has revealed synergistic interactions between neuro-modulation and pharmacotherapy.
studies have shown that eight weeks of mbct treatment during remission reduces relapse.
supportive gt and group cbt reduce depressive symptoms, especially in patients with common comorbid conditions.
mbct is a potential alternative to reduce, or even stop, antidepressant treatment without increasing the risk of depressive recurrence, especially for patients at a high risk of relapse.
ect is typically recommended for patients with severe and psychotic depression.
tdcs can be used as a complementary intervention or as monotherapy to reduce depressive symptoms in unipolar or bipolar depression patients.
vns is a therapeutic method that has been used for the last sixteen years to treat resistant unilateral or bipolar depression.
according to the literature, dbs of the subgenual cingulate white matter elicited a clinical response in 60% of resistant depression patients.
evidence supporting its effectiveness on depressive symptoms continues to grow.
ect remains the most documented and effective method in this category.
this treatment method is effective both for those with seasonal and non-seasonal depression.
vns has demonstrated progressively increasing improvements in depressive symptoms.
dbs elicited a clinical response in 60% of resistant depression patients after six months.
evidence supporting its effectiveness on depressive symptoms continues to grow.
ect remains the most documented and effective method in this category.
this treatment method is effective both for those with seasonal and non-seasonal depression.

a total of 2,876 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder, enrolled from 18 primary and 23 psychiatric care sites, received citalopram in level 1 of star*d.
in level 2, a total of 1,292 patients who did not remit with or tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned either to switch to bupropion.
in level 2, patients were randomly assigned either to switch to sertraline.
in level 2, patients were randomly assigned either to switch to venlafaxine.
patients were designated as having anxious depression if their anxiety/somatization factor score from the 17-item hamilton depression was 7 or higher at baseline.
anxious depression is associated with poorer acute outcomes than nonanxious depression following antidepressant treatment.
rates of remission and response as well as times to remission and response were compared between patients with anxious depression and those with nonanxious depression.
the authors conducted a secondary data analysis to compare antidepressant treatment outcomes for patients with anxious and nonanxious major depression in levels 1 and 2 of the star*d study.
patients were designated as having anxious depression if their anxiety/somatization factor score from the 17-item hamilton depression was 7 or higher at baseline.
ratings of side effect frequency, intensity, and burden, as well as the number of serious adverse events, were significantly greater in the anxious depression group.
the aim of citalopram treatment in level 1 was to achieve symptom remission.
the aim of citalopram treatment in level 1 was to achieve symptom remission, which was defined as qids-c score ≤5.
response was defined as a reduction of ≥50% from baseline in the qids score at the last assessment.
logistic regression models were used to compare remission and response rates after adjustment for baseline severity of depression.
patients completed the version of the qids.
patients with anxious depression made fewer visits and spent less time in treatment than those without anxious depression.
remission was defined as an exit ham-d score ≤7 or last observed qids score ≤5.
response was defined as a reduction of ≥50% from baseline in the qids score at the last assessment.

a total of 2,876 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder, enrolled from 18 primary and 23 psychiatric care sites, received citalopram in level 1 of star*d.
in level 2, a total of 1,292 patients who did not remit with or tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned either to switch to bupropion.
in level 2, patients were randomly assigned either to switch to sertraline.
in level 2, patients were randomly assigned either to switch to venlafaxine.
remission rates were significantly lower in patients with anxious depression...
response rates were also significantly lower for patients with anxious depression...
patients could discontinue citalopram before 12 weeks if intolerable side effects made a medication change necessary.

patients whose symptoms responded or remitted could enter the 12-month naturalistic follow-up phase, but all who did not achieve remission were encouraged to enter the next randomized trial in the star*d sequence.

interactions.source: clinical guidelines/FDA labeling (risk of serotonin syndrome; requires washout period)
clinical guidelines (risk of hypertensive crisis and severe adverse effects)
clinical guidelines (MAOI combined with SNRI poses high risk of serotonin syndrome/hypertensive events)
clinical guidelines (concomitant use can cause hypertensive reactions and other severe adverse events)
clinical pharmacology (fluoxetine inhibits CYP2D6, can increase TCA levels and toxicity)
clinical pharmacology (CYP interactions increasing TCA concentrations)
clinical guidelines/clinical pharmacology (risk of pharmacokinetic interactions and serotonin syndrome)
clinical guidelines (risk of serotonin syndrome)
clinical guidance (benzodiazepines can raise seizure threshold and may reduce ECT efficacy)
clinical studies (benzodiazepines may attenuate ketamine's antidepressant effect and increase sedation)
FDA labeling and clinical guidance (concomitant CNS depressants increase sedation; monitor closely)
drug labeling/clinical guidance (additive sedation and respiratory depression risk)
FDA labeling/clinical guidance (caution/avoid due to potential for exaggerated sympathetic effects and limited safety data)
preliminary research (relationships: synergistic interactions between neuromodulation and pharmacotherapy)
preliminary research (relationships indicate potential synergistic effects with pharmacotherapy)
relationships in provided data (combining somatic therapies and pharmacotherapy for resistant depression)
relationships in provided data (combination of medications and psychotherapy often more effective)
relationships in provided data (mbct may allow reduction/discontinuation of antidepressants in some patients)
clinical pharmacology/ECT guidance (bupropion lowers seizure threshold; caution regarding seizure control and potential prolonged seizures)
clinical pharmacology (concurrent serotonergic agents increase risk of serotonin syndrome)
psychotherapy literature (benzodiazepines may impair exposure-based learning and reduce effectiveness of some CBT components)
